p: Infected females can pass the bacteria to their offsprings and spread Wolbachia vertically from one generation to the next. Wolbachia disrupts the reproductive cycle of hosts through a cytoplasmic incompatibility between the sperms and eggs. Cytoplasmic incompatibility occurs when Wolbachia-infected male mosquitoes mate with Wolbachia-free female mosquitoes, and causes the Wolbachia-free females to produce fewer progeny [ 9, 10]. These effects provide the Wolbachia a vertical transmission advantage. However, this is offset by a reduced lifespan and reduced number of eggs hatched by a Wolbachia-infected mosquito.
